## How to Make a Natural Homemade Sunscreen

### Table of Contents
- [Introduction](#introduction)
- [Materials/Tools](#materials-tools)
- [Step-by-Step Procedure](#step-by-step-procedure)
- [Tips and Considerations](#tips-and-considerations)
- [Troubleshooting](#troubleshooting)
- [Safety Measures](#safety-measures)
- [Common Mistakes to Avoid](#common-mistakes-to-avoid)
- [Summary and Key Takeaways](#summary-and-key-takeaways)

### Introduction
Sunscreen is an essential part of protecting our skin from harmful UV rays. However, many commercial sunscreens contain chemicals that can be harmful to both our bodies and the environment. Making your own natural homemade sunscreen allows you to control the ingredients and ensure a safer and more eco-friendly option for sun protection. This guide will walk you through the process of making your own natural homemade sunscreen.

### Materials/Tools
- 1/4 cup coconut oil
- 1/4 cup shea butter
- 2 tablespoons zinc oxide powder
- 1 tablespoon beeswax pellets
- 10 drops of essential oil (optional)
- Double boiler or glass bowl and saucepan
- Whisk or spoon
- Measuring cups and spoons
- Glass jar or container with a lid

### Step-by-Step Procedure
1. Start by setting up your double boiler. If you don't have one, you can create a makeshift double boiler by placing a glass bowl over a saucepan filled with a few inches of water.
2. Add the coconut oil, shea butter, and beeswax pellets to the double boiler or glass bowl. Heat the water in the saucepan or the double boiler over low heat until the ingredients melt and combine.
3. Once the mixture has melted, remove it from the heat and let it cool for a few minutes.
4. Carefully add the zinc oxide powder to the mixture. Use a whisk or spoon to thoroughly mix it in, ensuring there are no clumps.
5. If desired, add 10 drops of your preferred essential oil to give your sunscreen a pleasant scent. Stir well to incorporate the essential oil.
6. Allow the mixture to cool completely before transferring it to a glass jar or container with a lid. This may take a few hours, so be patient.
7. Once cooled, your homemade sunscreen is ready to use. Apply it liberally to exposed skin before going out in the sun. Reapply every two hours or more frequently if sweating or swimming.

### Tips and Considerations
- Choose a broad-spectrum zinc oxide powder to ensure protection against both UVA and UVB rays.
- Be cautious when handling zinc oxide powder, as it can be harmful if inhaled. Wear a mask or work in a well-ventilated area.
- If you prefer a thicker sunscreen, you can increase the amount of beeswax pellets in the recipe.
- Store your homemade sunscreen in a cool, dry place to extend its shelf life.

### Troubleshooting
- If your homemade sunscreen feels too greasy, reduce the amount of coconut oil or shea butter in the recipe.
- If the sunscreen doesn't spread easily, you can add a small amount of a lighter oil, such as jojoba oil, to the mixture.

### Safety Measures
- When working with hot ingredients, be careful to avoid burns. Use oven mitts or a towel to handle hot containers.
- Protect your eyes from any potential splashes or fumes when working with the ingredients.
- Perform a patch test on a small area of skin before applying the homemade sunscreen to your entire body to check for any allergic reactions.

### Common Mistakes to Avoid
- Avoid using citrus essential oils in your homemade sunscreen, as they can make your skin more sensitive to sunlight.
- Ensure that the zinc oxide powder is thoroughly mixed into the sunscreen to ensure even sun protection.

### Summary and Key Takeaways
Making your own natural homemade sunscreen allows you to have control over the ingredients and ensure a safer and more eco-friendly option for sun protection. By following the step-by-step procedure and considering the tips and safety measures, you can create a sunscreen that provides effective protection against harmful UV rays. Remember to reapply regularly and store your homemade sunscreen properly for optimal results.
